posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Whatever you do, keep in mind you need energy to draw.

- The job must either be stress-free, short OR seasonal. For instance, my friend works at an oil extraction platform. He works like crazy for 15 days straight, living at the plant. Then, he takes 15-day breaks, which you could use to draw.

- Leeching off of your parents is one thing, becoming 100% independent is another. If you can afford to just contribute to the house expenses, you don't need THAT fancy of a job, just the bare minimum to not be deadweight at home while you work on your skills. Remember, in you case getting enough time to draw is more important than getting large sums of money, otherwise you wouldn't be an aritst.

- Once you start working, in case it's a daily job, make sure you draw BEFORE work so you don't arrive home with no energy to do anything. Go to bed early, wake up early, drawdrawdraw. If you can draw DURING work, that's a different story, but doing both is still great mileage.

Good luck, nonners.

>>6516844
>>6517264
I worked at factories (construction industry, even) in the anglosphere for years and it’s backbreaking work.
Constant production over capacity, everyone on edge because it is literally impossible to meet quotas, equipment failing all around you because there is no time to do maintenance, pressure from the management to not just bend, but outright ignore and/or forge SOPs and quality/safety tests while simultaneously telling you how you definitely need to do them wink wink, asking you to do overtime every fucking week, the pay is shit for new hires because the conditions are so bad average turnaround of fresh meat is ~1 month, etc etc
I don’t think I drew 300 hours total outside of vacation time in those 3 years, I was doing 42 hours a week minimum, very commonly 50+, shit was breaking down everywhere (one guy lost a leg because a crane failed, he got blamed for not ensuring the crane was in working condition, the SOP was amended so you have to sign that you checked the equipment before using it, of course nobody actually does it be they’re not fucking engineers and have no time to do it anyway, meanwhile the engineers sit around doing fuckall all day), you’re standing on concrete in full gear and the worst boots mankind ever invented, you lift literal tons of shit all day even as a machine operator, the commute is long because factories aren’t usually near residential areas, some factories are basically two walls with a roof so it’s cold as fuck in winter and hot as fuck in summer, I even managed to get fucking fleas working there

I can only imagine what kind of hell working in a factory in Mexico or Romania would be

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6517532
Oh, and I actually started avoiding walking under tall buildings, that’s how bad the standards are. We had actual literal third worlders come in to work and be appalled at what we’re producing. Muh western quality is such a fucking meme.

Those were all big, big factories and companies, thousand+ workers on the plant floor, factories all over the country.
I’ve been told the small companies both pay better and have lower throughput, but I was so sick of living I just saved money and quit to neet it up.

>>6520438
>how is it so far
I mean, you've basically got your quintessential Twitter animu style if you cleaned up your shapes and pushed the contrast/sharpness a bit - especially on her sleeves. I can't really say much more without an idea of what you're striving towards.
>basically I start with a mid tone and add lights and a bit of shadows afterwards
Eh, I don't think the order really matters, just make sure you're defining the extreme ranges in all of hue, saturation, and value as early as possible as your eyes can get acclimated to lifeless colors real quick. Tinkering with levels as you go is also a real lifesaver, don't feel bad about it.

If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

READ THE STICKY:
Completed: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uwaXKU7ev6Tw_or__o8ARpUb6r2rCZYJGqwSFV9AD98/edit

Old: http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-draw-learn

RECOMMENDED BOOKS FOR BEGINNERS:
Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.
When giving feedback, avoid vague "advice" - point what's wrong and try to give the anon you're quoting a clear direction to improve their art (study heads < watch THIS VIDEO about head structure, read THIS SECTION of THIS ARTIST'S BOOK, etc).
You, feedback seeking anon, should also try to be clear and concise when asking for critique/help. When posting your artwork, say what you want help with, and what's your goal with the study/artwork.

>>6519690
try the pose yourself, it might help a bit.
the forearm is a little too long and the upper arm a little too short. when i do the pose my forearm angles in towards my wrist. also if they're supposed to be putting gloves on tightly, consider rearranging the pose a little. when i adjust my gloves my thumb indexes under the front of the glove/back of my hand. my elbow is also angled a little bit downwards so that it's easier to pull on the glove. that also means the right arm would be turned more inwards so that the fist is facing more towards the chin. you can adjust gloves the way you have it drawn, but it really only feels like you're getting your last 3 fingers while missing the index and thumb
either way though that's just from the way i do wear gloves. you should find a pair and try it yourself in front of a mirror (bunny ears optional)

posts.com:
>>6519592
The irises are different shapes and the shading/lighting of the eyes look wobbly (though the lighting principles are spot-on, it just looks rough). Honestly though, the eyes are not what sticks out to me here. The difference in line thickness really sticks out with the chin and it gives it a weird appearance. Also the alignment of the chin/mouth looks off and needs adjusting in lieu of the mouth shape. Honestly just from experience, getting that part right is one of the biggest hurdles for people aspiring to draw anime. Also when it comes to line drawing, if you're going for a rough sketchy style make it apparent, otherwise the rough edges on just comes across as laziness in people's eyes. Basically pick a style that suits you, whether it's more sketchy/freehand or if you want clean linework (I know it's a study but it's something to take note when you're finalizing your line art).

I apologize if I sound like I'm ragging on you, but I'm only critiquing because I can tell that you have potential in getting this right. Pic-rel might help in illustrating my suggestions. I made an edit with the adjustments but I feel bad about editing someone else's work without their permission unless you're okay with me posting it.

>>6521570
Here's my two second fix, though if I were to invest more time in it, I'd most likely go looking for a strong model pose reference, rather than trying to wing it.

The major issue is the left shoulder. For the head to be that far forwards, the left shoulder would need to also come forwards, since the right one is being pulled back so far. The shoulders have to twist along with the torso. So the left shoulder should be right under the torso, and it looks like you made the arm way to long, so I pushed it in, making the elbow also tucked under the body since the upper arm shouldn't be that long.

I think it's salvageable, though it is a tough pose to do without strong reference.

posts.com:
The general thread for Manga / manga-styled comic-making, manga-style illustration and related comic work.

Support each other and talk about your work or the work of others that excites you. Inking, character design, paneling / layout, writing, planning, and other discussions are all welcome.
Post resources, questions, in-progress pages, breakdowns of other works, etc. If a work is not yours, credit the maker (unless it's fucking obvious like a full page of One Piece or something).
Thanks to everyone for making /mmg/ a level-headed and helpful place. Remember, drawing and making comics and manga are difficult endeavors, and we're all in this struggle together.

Previous thread: >>6478292

Some resources:
/asg/, our stylistic sister-thread series for those focused more on illustration >>>/ic/asg

Understanding Comics
Making Comics
Manga in Theory and Practice: The Craft of Creating Manga

The Shonen Jump Guide to Making Manga

Some western / indie publishers of Manga:

Saturday AM ( https://www.saturday-am.com/ )
> Digital indie magazine, seems to be on the up-and-up
> Open submissions for long-form series; also distributes series currently being published elsewhere.
> Regularly publishes one-shots, making it a good potential outlet for already-finished work.

Noir Caesar ( https://www.noircaesar.com/ )
> Focuses on black (specifically African-American) content, but seems willing to publish anyone good enough.
> Seemingly series-based only.
> No "magazine" style updates; series are updated on their own schedule.
> Seems less regular than Saturday AM, but also seems larger in terms of readership.

Oni Press ( https://onipress.com/ )
> Technically indie, but at this point large enough by comic standards to be mentioned in the same breath as other publishers.

Antarctic Press ( https://antarctic-press.myshopify.com/ )
> Longtime large-indie publisher of OEL / manga-esque books.
> Seemingly taking submissions at present if http://www.antarctic-press.com/html/submissions.php is anything to go on.

Yen Press ( https://yenpress.com/ )
> Started out as a small indie publisher of original / Korean material, and has grown reasonably popular since.
> As of 2016, it is also one of the western arms of the Kadokawa Corporation, with Kadokawa owning a 51% stake.
> Editorial inquiries can apparently be sent to yenpress@yenpress.com, however, they apparently are not open to new submissions at this time.

Viz Media / Viz Originals ( https://www.viz.com/originals )
> *The* western manga publisher.
> Currently in the exploratory stages of setting up an English label.
> Submissions are open and several books have been announced. However, progress on the label seems to be moving very slowly.
> Still might be worth a shot anyway.

Shrine Comics ( https://shrinecomics.com/ )
> Small indie manga publisher
> Seemingly attempting to make the transition to physical volumes
> Allows crossposting to other sites

How are your profits? Do advertise your work outside of this place?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6497881
Hi anon. I mainly make profits from selling my books and original page art at art shows and comic and anime conventions. I fund my print runs with crowdfunding campaigns, and then sell the books for pure profit at shows. My evergreen bestseller is Purrvana, a colorful watercolor painted psychedelic cat graphic novel that appeals to normies of all ages and all demographics from bikers to gangsters to grannies to crazy cat ladies. I have sold over 2,500 copies of Purrvana to date. I also make money from commissions, both my OCs and other people. Most of my commissions are catfight wrestling matches featuring my OCs or other people's OCs. I advertise mainly on pixiv, discord, twitter and my webcomic also works as an advertisement. I also drew animal coloring books years ago that still sell, at shows and online. After a bad experience working with a publisher several years ago, I began self publishing and now that's all I want to do.

I read that Image creators are in the red and go in to debt with Image unless their book sells a certain amount of copies. I recently read tweets from an image artist who says that after his book he worked on sold 5 issues at 15,000 issues each, he only made $1100 in profit and he got paid months after the final issue came out, after the profit share was split with image, the writer and colorist. I don't sell a high volume of copies, and my crowdfunders don't go crazy, but I still make a lot more profit than that Image artist whose book was selling 15,000 copies each issue for example because I keep all the profit of sales for myself. I also do freelance work. Advertising and marketing is not really something I'm good at, but I'm getting by and trying to improve at it. I'm also going to start a life drawing class at my local Junior College next week and I hope it will up my skills so I can charge more for commissions, and it will also improve my comic pages. No rest for the wicked.

Isekai is the manga equivalent of dime romance novels you see in bookstores written for middle aged women and angsty teenage girls and weird maladjusted twenty something men. Only difference is the genders are flipped.

There's no such thing as an original idea. What matters is how you use the idea. Make something good, and it will be 'original' by simply the fact you made it. You leak into your good works, and one of the defining trait of bad works is often when that doesn't happen.

>>6498314
>But now Im starting feel the idea is over done and Im wondering if I should revise it.
As long you have a unique 'twitst' or take on the genre then you'll still stand out in an oversaturated market.
I'd even go as far as say it can be advantageous to use a popular genre/setting like isekai because your audience will immediatly know what to expect.
>"It's an isekai with cool battles, knights, monsters and magic? It's just like the other isekai's I love!"
You can essentially bait an audience and have fun with it by subverting isekai tropes and expectations.
>"that isekai by anon isn't like your average isekai! It looks generic at the beginning but slowly turns into this super deep subversion of the genre. It's fucking peak fiction!"

That's for example the kind of comments isekais like Mushoku Tensei, Re:Zero, Tanya the evil and Konosuba get.
>"It's an isekai but without the shitty writing and blatant power fantasy elements. I swear it's good!"

It's great that you're questioning your creative direction and want to find a unique and fresh angle for your comic. I recommend researching other cultures and periods of time for inspiration. This will allow you to broaden your perspective and bring new and innovative ideas to your work. You can also consider incorporating elements of other genres, like science fiction, to add an extra layer of uniqueness to your story. By exploring different cultures, time periods and genres you'll have the opportunity to create a world that is truly your own and stands out in a sea of comics.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6506118
I write up a rough outline, then do dialogue, then do another pass and at least one rewrite before I start on chapter 2, then I keep going until the entire thing is written and I don't have a single page drawn because I'm eternally ngmi
Then I start it all over again with a new idea

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6506118
I write the dialogue right onto the page, using it as a sort of marker for where the panel's going to be (also using a brief non-dialogue description of the panel if there's no dialogue I think I might forget what's supposed to go there) for a few pages at a time, then I go back and quickly storyboard it. I do this in chunks of 2-5 pages at a time, not really coinciding with scenes or anything. This allows me to work out the pacing, phrasing and dialogue all at once.

Her sensei wasn't the reason she succeeded in manga though. >>6509961
>Demon Slayer outsold the entire western comic industry by itself.

"It is important to contextualize where these numbers came from to begin with. Matrix cites Otaku USA, which in turn cites Anime News Network. The ANN article in question is about Demon Slayer's sales in Japan for the October 19-25 week in 2020, according to Oricon. Though not part of the headline story, the article states that the series had 100 million copies in circulation (including digital copies, which Oricon does not count), not sales, as of the 22nd volume's release on October 2.

Neither ANN nor Otaku USA reported on American comic book sales. The video version of Matrix's article indicates that his source for the "15 million" number is a sankaku Complex article, which in turn cites comic book blog The Beat's analysis of NPD BookScan data for 2019. It should be noted that the analysis is restricted only to the top 750 titles, so the 15 million figure applies only to that selection. It should also be noted that BookScan only represents a selection of retailers, and is not representative of the entire market.

That said, even the 15 million figure from The Beat's limited-scope analysis is a lower amount than Oricon's reported sales figures for Demon Slayer in 2019: 12 million copies. That figure is also disputed; publisher Shueisha reported that the manga sold 10.8 million volumes that year. So Demon Slayer clearly didn't outsell the American comics industry in the same frame of time. By conflating Demon Slayer's lifetime circulation numbers with yearly sales and stacking them against partial sales numbers in the American market for 2019, the numbers provided in Matrix's article paint a misleading picture."

And this source came from a anime focused website . YA and creator owned series do well in sales . The only real decline in sales is coming from marvel and dc(which is a good thing).

How do I get off the perfectionist mindset?
I wanna make a comic and publish it in Webtoon or Tapas or whatever.
I have the general plot roadmap , the bible, and the feel, but I lack the art. Kind of.
Seeing the general art mastery of the average webcomic (shit the general starting mangaka) artist, I think I'm on the 60% percentile. Not because I'm very good, but because they're shit.
And even then, actual drawing ability is usually not that important to the success of a webcomic/manga and sometimes you're even expected to get better as you publish it.
Yet, whenever I'm about to start making it, I stop because I wanna do something I clearly don't have the ability to pull yet, and it comes out like shit and get frustrated.
How do I accommodate my content closer to my current ability? Should I lower my ambitions on my art? That seems counterproductive, how do I improve then?
How do I bite the bullet, accept it looks like shit but is the best I can do and publish it?

I was in the same boat and started at 30. It takes around 5 years to git gud no matter if you are 20 or 30. The problem is that sacrificing 5 years is a lot more difficult when you are 30. There is also a growing pride that will be in your way the older you get, especially if you are already competent in your field and have to go back being a nobody and producing bad drawings at that age. There is an upside to it, you value it more, you are more disciplined than your 20yo self. You have life experience. Imagine doing art as early as possible, going straight into an art school and art being the only thing you did in your life. It's easy to lose touch with normal people, produce cringe art and fall into some narcissistic "muh style" trap. See it from the good side, there is a lot of shit you will avoid without even thinking about it.

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.
>Don’t copy recklessly. Use construction, color theory, and other fundamental concepts to rehearse a drawing process that you can later easily manipulate for original artwork.
>Post all of your anime studies. Post even when you’re told not to. Create an art community that actually draws and improves together instead of just talking about it.
>Number your attempts and link to your previous posts.
>Critiquers should lead by example by posting their studies.

General Anime Style Discussion:
>Questions about achieving certain styles/techniques/compositions etc.
>Drawing methods, study habits, resources, tutorials, tools, software, etc
>Be specific and try to post a sample of your study attempts before asking for help.

**Draw copies from good anime styled references to mindfully up our mileage, internalize appealing aesthetics, and learn from each other’s processes and knowledge.**

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6517868
Yes.

It doesn't have to be a perfect circle, the circle is more or less just there to inform your proportions. Obviously if the circle is wide or oblong, and you use it as an outline without any thought at all, you end up with a wide or oblong head.

The more important step is the guidelines (usually the cross looking thing) that whatever guide you're reading will tell you to drop on to the head next. If you read Loomis he'll teach you how to carve up the circle, cutting the sides off and hanging a jawline off of it, but the guidelines accomplish the same thing with different methods. Those guidelines will usually tell you your eye line (center of the eye) or your brow line, which you use to figure out your nose and mouth lines as well.

Post your work or just some exercises done right now, that will give us a clearer picture of what part of the process might be confusing you, or which parts of the process you aren't yet aware of.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6519420
the defaut loomis head is an idealized representation of the head of an adult caucasian male
but loomis himself in the book says that if everyone had the same facial proportions everyone would have the same face and recommends changing proportions for different characters

to give the cute anime girl look, the chin cannot be too long, which will make the distance from the chin to the nose no longer equal the distance from the eyebrows to the nose, then relationship between proportions changes from eyebrow:nose:chin to eyes:nose:chin

but the truth is that this varies from artist to artist, so there is no recipe that will work for all characters, so I recommend that you choose a single artist to study and preferably someone with whom you want to have a similar style

>>6517151
It's good to copy like that sometimes to better train your eye, but for the life of me I don't see how people who turn every copy into an labored measuring of angles and shapes are improving much beyond pure observational drawing skill. At a certain point you forget/ignore that you're drawing a cartoon dog or whatever and are just copying lines and shapes - which is totally fine if you're wanting a 1:1 copy, but not super helpful if you're trying to build a visual library and understand form and how to better draw the thing for your own creations. Ideally you'll reach a point where you can somewhat seamlessly combine observational skills with awareness of and the general construction of the subject without having to entirely break down whatever you're drawing into an amalgamation of measured lines and abstract shapes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

>>6466732
I don't think you really understand what the term "master study" means judging by the crap you've been spamming anon.

A "master study" implies you're studying from an artist you consider well-rounded and of a higher, established skill level. You do so in order to break down and understand the process behind the picture, akin to reverse-engineering it. It has nothing to do with them being born centuries ago or having their works on a museum's wall. Even studying someone else's study can be considered a master study.
The medium and style said artist is using only matters to you. If you believe Miyazaki's drawings possess something you want to extract and instill into your own art, then he is a master to you and studying his work counts as a master study. Same goes for some famous Twitter artist you look up to.

Forcing an anti-Japanese culture narrative or pretending to objectify what should be valued as masterful or not in the end just tells more about you people's petty complexes more than anything else.

>>6473037
He's showing the front plane of the pectorals. This plane is bounded laterally by a line from the clavicle (specifically, the point on the front at which the clavicle curves backward) to the bottom outer limit of the pectoral (just a little below/outside the nipple). From that bottom/outer point, an oblique line going toward the point of the shoulder is the base of another triangular plane, which is the side plane of the pectoral.

>>6504329
>I want to get better at painting. My skill in line art and painting arent equal and its time to fix it.
if your goal/assignment isn't to use a particular construction method for now, and you can just copy what you see, then I recommend mentally detaching it from your drawing habits. think more about shapes and edges instead of lines, especially during your block in phase; the whole picture as irregular, interlocking, straight-edged shapes. think about it in terms of light and shadow if the source allows. block ins are the most important thing to get right. mark tennant is an awesome painter who basically just does block ins.

I can give more info or critique if you want, but here's are some lines I drew over your (modified) ref to illustrate. the yellow is an envelope with too many edges, and the green is to sort of highlight what I would casually consider to be barriers between light and shadow.

dorian iten has some really good videos about it that I recommend. I find that over time, his advice is what sticks for me and has helped me the most. his advice helped me a lot with accuracy, identifying value relationships, and thinking about process.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zZ0lz7W0CYs

>>6521252
If you're going to draw something like this, you either use reference or wait until you're so well versed in anatomy, perspective, form, etc. that you can wing it convincingly. If it looks right, it's right. The problem with drawing poses in extreme perspective like this is that even a photo can look "off," so your drawing from said photo will be judged as inaccurate even if you reproduced the image 1:1. This is why artists from antiquity on through the 19th century tended to paint figures in poses with most of the limbs seen at full length. Perspective lens distortion within a figure was almost unheard of, and even foreshortening was used with caution. Typically, a foreshortened limb or figure would have to be coupled with a full-length limb/figure so the viewer had a "reference" by which to judge the foreshortened parts. Coom art drawn from close-up reference photos with lense distortion is aesthetically less pleasing than, say, a Bouguereau, but coomers have horrible taste and only care about seeing monster tits on their FOTM anime girl so they can cry, "Momma!" while jerking it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6518820
It's a 4chan board, buddy. Lots of people ask for shadow/value advice. We can't write a book each time.
Study your favorite art, do value studies on objects/pics with extreme lighting, and learn how shadows interact with the body. Hold your fist up to a harsh light, take a picture, and replicate it. Shine a flashlight on your/someone's face, and draw that. Draw a bunch of interlocking shapes, decide on a lighting direction, and shade that. Look up videos on YouTube.
Before you learn to shade, you should be learning how the various volumes of the subject interact. For example, you could essentially reduce the human arm to a series of smushed together ovoid objects (muscles). Then you can refine the shadows further after you've determined the initial volume.
Also learn about ambient occlusion and bounce light.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6514096
I would be careful just repeating stuff mindlessly what art historians claim. Keep in mind they don't draw and get educated in an environment devoid of any classically trained artists. Note how there is no dialog between art historians and modern masters of painting and master draftsmen, it is to a huge part due to ego and disdain towards "craftsmen". The camera obscura theory claims that the main problem is a problem of accuracy or the drawing, which is not true. It is a big problem to most of us, but there is a compositional challenge, how to arrange stuff, choosing the perspective. I am baffled how educated people just sum the process up to "camera obscura" and just leave it there, like a mystery is solved in one word. Look at the figures, think about the actual challenge of painting in a camera obscura opposed to having drawing skills. Take a look at how masterfully he painted the horses in a few strokes and think again if a "drawing aid" would be helpful or an actual hinderance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6514124

That was sarcasm, sorry. The "..." and all. Good points.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6514122
I think they are artificially constructed from careful sketches on location. I assume that after sketching for many weeks he would decide for a composition and then plot out a perspective grid on the final piece and place the buildings in this high up perspective. Like you would recreate a City in a 3D program, but in this case it's a fixed perspective. I am not sure of the accuracy of the paintings, even though I was in Dresden several times, but I would lean towards agreeing and say they are somewhat inaccurate but it makes the whole scene more grand and he fits more stuff in than would be able to see.

This is all my personal speculation though, it would need a more careful analysis for someone actually to really check it from the exact same viewpoints. The fact that all the viewpoints are high up makes it difficult to check if you were just walking around there like me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6505842
The only thing Aesprite gives you that CSP doesn't is pixel perfect lines, which is a huge timesaver. You can get that on free alternatives like Libresprite and PixilArt.
I used to use CSP for pixel art, but the brush engine is too enthusiastic to lay points down, and there's next to no color management for controlling palettes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6509664
I should add that Aseprite has color and palette management, unlike CSP. Color and contrasts are what carry pixel art, so that's important.
That being said, unless you're looking to get away from CSP, you should look up the pixel tools in the assets store if you haven't done so already. They're fun to play with.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6513704
Professional anon here:
I have the cintiq 16 and I think it's basically all around the best tablet out there. Only downside is that it has no built in buttons.

It's a decent size, not too big, not too small, very portable if you want to shift stuff around. Screen resolution isn't super hd, but I don't think you need it. The screen is just small enough that you'll probably never get close enough to it to really notice the pixel density.

Furthermore, this is an underrated fact but it's extremely important. I think it's a really durable tablet. The cintiq 16 pro is nice and all, but it's way over priced and far less durable than the 16. The glass is very thin and the pixels are lamenated to the glass so just imagine drawing on your regular monitor with a wacom pen all day, yeah you're going to fuck up your monitor. that's what the 16 pro is like.

Lastly is the price. It's not cheap, but it's not overly expensive either if you plan on really using it.

Overall, if you want wacom's precision and you want a screen tablet. I think the 16 is all around the best for most artists.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6514855
I genuinely cannot fathom why people get in a tisy over slight paralax. It's absolutely baffling to me. I even explicitly calibrate my pen so the cursor is slightly offset so I can better see what I'm doing. I've convinced a few of my coworkers to do the same and they haven't gone back. I'd recommend you try it too, you'd be surprised how little parallax really matters.

But anyway, the main point I brought up about the laminated display is that it's extremely easy to damage the pixels with such thin glass. Even just your light palm pressure on the screen is enough to damage it over time. The cintiq 22pro doesn't have this issue because the glass is thicker.

I'm back.

I take back what I said earlier, ...kinda. I really don't care which brand or operating system I have for my next tablet and/or touch-screen laptop, I just need something with good pen sensitivity. I'll even use a Linux OS distro if I have to. I'd like the screen to be bookbag-friendly & be 17 inches or smaller.

I am working on my 2nd illustrated poem book. This book is different since I am keeping the rhymes cleaner, and getting more inspiration from MF DOOM and Shel Silverstein rather than airing out my "R-rated" world grievances from my first book.

For my first book, the illustrations were less detail-oriented being 101 poems with 101 inanimate objects brought to life through my words. For my first book, it didn't really matter how extreme the specs were for the tools I was using because my illustrations didn't need as much detail.

My second book does have more detail because each poem has an animal in representation of my words (pic related). These animals have more details like scales and fur that my first book did not.

I've decided I am going to be patient with this. Although I have the money now to afford some sorta 8000+ pressure sensitivity tablet/laptop, I think I may stick with my low-end Samsung Tab S6-Lite to finish off my second book. I have about 10 illustrations already made up for my second book. I don't want there to be inconsistencies with having a better tablet for my second book.

>>6513705
They're good, but basically brand new second hand tablets seem to get put up for sale by art students all of the time, either because they're not interested or they're upgrading.

So, between $150 for a basically new new kamvas 13, or $200 for basically new cintiq, you're better off with the cintiq. With actually new tablets, I think it's wasting your money and maybe some people have it in their head that even if the slightly second hand premium tablet is in mint condition, a month or two of pristine use time is somehow worth 500 extra dollars for an technically inferior product with a worse screen or worse sensitivity.

Like, I bought a new kamvas last year, and then later returned it and got a second hand cintiq in great condition. The screens were more or less the same, the sensitivity was the same, but the huion pen was kind of bad, and there no option to change it or even the nibs for something nicer. Like a goddamn ice rink. $200 for something I avoided using vs $300 I use whenever I have even a little excuse to. But do you need to pay wacom $1000 for a brand new one? No, no way, don't be retarded. Save that $700, get yourself a bunch of other nice things, too.

i'm using the kamvas pro 16 for more than two years i think, yeah, and yes the laminated screen is a deal breaker. I work almost daily and to this day the screen has zero marks, lines, scratches. annoying, use some fan or something to cool your arm.

>>6511106
a guy once just seemed lonely and wanted to talk to me about his dog. Just treat them as you would if you were working behind the counter in retail (this honestly is what helped me stop having autism spaghetti, people just want to talk and be kind to each other mostly, and it's likely they want to try and be your friend so you just have to accept that and try to keep your distance relatively). Respond kindly and say things like "yeah I had a pet like that, I can relate" and if you think of something to ask that you're actually interested in like "have you trained your dog to do any tricks?" then ask but don't try and have an extended conversation, just like "Well that's cool"

Idk man I'm on the spectrum somewhere.

Tell me what he wants to talk about, he probably just wants you to be yourself, meaning if you don't wanna talk, be brief. I try and type half the words they do so the conversation peters out generally idk

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6511987
Good points anon. The "ask about things that actually interested me" thing is hard to pull off in practice, but it perhaps it just needs more practice. They'd mention one thing that sparked my interest, but by the time I wrote a question about it, they'd already move on to a slightly different subject or ask a question on their own.
There's also problem of open questions. I feel that I can't be brief with them (like you suggested) without coming off as dismissive.

At the end of the day I DO want them to like me and to have fun talking to me. I just don't know how to learn this, where to even start.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6512060
>have fun talking to me
I think that's a literally impossible goal with a stranger and you'll be causing a weird conversation if you try and make jokes or relate to them on a deeper level than you know them, the most you can do is match them. If they ask a question, then answer and if it leads to another question in your mind then ask. The conversation should always just be respectful and friendly, like someone wants to buy something from your IRL shop, and maybe they notice you're wearing a nice shirt and they comment on it or something so you respond and say you like their shoes or something. It's not really something you can quantify or prepare yourself for, some people are weird, some people are awesome. Just try to be respectful and truthful in the moment. Trying not to drop your spaghetti and say something weird for me literally just took watching my coworkers deal with the weirdos (I worked near a hospital). Smiling and nodding.
Man I am not a good person to ask.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6512060
cont I guess
>They'd mention one thing that sparked my interest, but by the time I wrote a question about it, they'd already move on to a slightly different subject or ask a question on their own.
it sounds like they want to do the talking, so don't worry about it. Human interaction takes getting used to and it's not something to be fearful of as long as you're being friendly and responding to things they ask and not treating them like you haven't got the time (unless you really haven't)
I empathise with your thoughts a lot and it's how I felt when I first had to talk to customers IRL "am I doing this right" "is this too rude or dismissive" and really the only answer is to use informal friendly language and be truthful in the moment, that's all you can do, and the self doubt can fuck right off because you're doing your best. do it enough and you won't even worry if you're doing it right.

>>6506446
gotcha. forgive me if you know all this, but just so we're on the same page:
not sure what resources you're using to study with but they should cover thinking about the figure in terms of it's component 3d 'forms', i.e. the ribcage, pelvis, head, two forms for each arm and leg, hands and feet. this is a 'constructive' approach to figure drawing that has you orient these 3d forms on the page in positions corresponding to what you see in the reference. it feels basically the same as posing an action man as you get better at drawing 3d objects (boxes, spheres, basic perspective).
so anyway, all that is a long way to set up that when I say 'an oval for the ribcage', try to visualise the ribcage in the figure you're drawing and mark that down as an oval on the page, and do something similar for all the forms in the figure. loomis and hampton and vilppu can all teach you what shapes you can use.

>>6506442
fair enough, whatever works for you.
but I'll say that I felt much the same way. the first couple of days drawing in silence were like scraping nails across a chalk board. but after not too long a clarity set in and I'm able to focus a lot better now. I'm not able to overthink in the silence because all of my attention is turned to the task of drawing (when all is going well).
so it went: 50% drawing, 50% yt/music, 0% bullshit thoughts
to: 50% drawing, 50% bullshit thoughts
to: 100% drawing, 0% bullshit thoughts
but the process of getting to that point takes time, is painful and I'm not always there, you have to stay vigilant and keep on yourself to focus on the drawing at hand. it's tough! but when you're 100% in that zone, like a surfer in the tube like in surfs up, nothing feels better.

don't know your particular circumstance, maybe you've got adhd or what have you, but I can say for me it was probably a simple case of frying my brain with constant stimulation. checking the phone first thing when you wake up etc..

I would recommend starting with just changing a limb or two to start with. You can also draw a reference from a different angle. Re-drawing a figure from memory helps too. Redrawing something you just drew shows you what you need to work on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6512542
Getting a full figure down quickly helps. Once you can see the whole figure, it's easier to notice what is off. With less strokes on the page it's easier to fix the mistakes too. With a gesture drawing approach likes Glenn Vilppus, about 30 seconds is enough to get the major masses and limbs down. At that point I just check that the hips are at about halfway of the length of the figure and visually measure that it's around 7 to 8 heads tall, that's usually enough. For longer drawings or harder poses, more time is spent double checking stuff. You may find you keep making the same proportional mistakes, so that's something you can study and be on the lookout for.
A lot of the time you have to deal with foreshortened limbs and overlapping forms so it takes a lot of practice. There is also choosing what to exaggerate or idealize. For example, you can make the legs longer and it will usually look better, so when in doubt you can make them a bit longer.

Basically this. I was fascinated when I learned how solid the non-JP comic industries were. American underground and indie comics were a crapshoot, mostly consisting of slice-of-life self-insert shit since quality control in those comics only existed in capeshit, but could still be a goldmine and a second option. Webcomics put more on the table and showed what the potential could be. Things like The Walking Dead were a strong exception to our industry. But, in other countries, a title like that would be on the upper standard and not a rarity.
I really believe that the reason why the capeshit print side is hurting is due to the fact America shoehorned comics from being a luxury/fine art industry like in the late 1800s-early 1900s, to being something for kids and all about superheroes. Kind of like how animation here went from being something for adults, to being for kids w/most of our adult titles being comedies working on low budgets.

posts.sub: how do you calculate angles in perspective?
posts.com: im trying to draw a line that is perpendicular to the red one in a 2-point perspective scene.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6520942
What does perpendicular mean

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6520951
>perpendicular
at an angle of 90° to a given line, plane, or surface or to the ground.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6520942
Find the station point.
Did you know that the left and right vanishing points are ALWAYS 90 degrees visually from the station point? This is because this represents the point where the viewer/camera is from the picture plane. Closer that point is to the horizon line, closer they are to the object/scene, farther away it is, farther the camera. What this means is that once you find this, you can find any angle from a flat view on the page and translate it into perspective by rotating it around the station point. Wherever the lines hit from the station point onto the Horizon line will be your new Measuring points for those angles you desire.
This is how you figure out 45 measuring point for getting square grids and what have you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6520942
Establish a flat station point (that is, the point in which the viewer is standing) and project from it a straight angle to the horizon line, which you can use as vanishing points for your perpendiculars

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6520974
The Complete Guide to Perspective Drawing by Craig Atterbery (pic related).

He's a teacher at ArtCenter like Scott Robertson is and whenever his students would ask him unique questions that he couldn't immediately answer, he would research it and then make handouts for them. Eventually that turned into a book. It's extremely technical, even more than Robertson's book, but it exhaustively covers almost everything there is to know about perspective and answers a lot of small questions like this.

>>6520988
Sorry I just meant that I didn't do any construction (I could've done something like picrel). You definitely don't need a protractor because there's no reality you have to be faithful to, the scene only start to exist as you put it in on paper. Your first line by itself has little meaning, the second line you choose draw, no matter the angle, will never be incorrect, it will just be close or far away. The first couple lines of a drawing have almost no constraints, the constraint is what you want the scene to communicate

>>6520965
I was able to find a pdf for free online easily and can confirm that it's good. The intro pages should show you everything. If you like video instructions and examples though, I heavily reccommend Drawing Database perspective series. It's the most in depth formal perspective I've seen for artists, go through that and you will understand all the concepts. (dont just watch it either, try and actually DO the drawings with the instructor and that will make them sink in your long term memory). You might have to come back and review stuff, which is where this book might come in handy, as well as the videos. Good luck.
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLqZPT9FWy84Xt2b117tzwZcFXEF8rG6Yy

posts.com: Hey, /trad/. I'm learning how to properly ink with a variety of pens (dip pens, fine liners, etc.), but I'm still at that stage where the thought of mistakes over a perfectly good sketch...well, has kept me from refining that skillet. I've been looking to invest in a lightbox, but would that work with paper as thick as cardstock and Bristol boards? If not a lightbox, is there something else you suggest so I can build confidence without potentially ruining the originals? I sold three graphite sketches featuring my OCs in a month. It would help me a great deal with developing my skills and financially. Thank you very much in advance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6509159
>but would that work with paper as thick as cardstock and Bristol boards?
Yep, literally what they're made for. Caveat: If your pencil sketch is messy, it will be a little difficult. In that case, here's what you do:
>scan drawing
>flip drawing
>print
>trace using carbon paper/tracing paper
>transfer
>ink that

Alternatively:
>scan
>fix your dirty ass drawing in Photoshop
>print with adjusted contrast
>put under lightbox and pretend like you know how to draw without erasing 500 times and drawing the world's messiest lines

Not the same guy, but in my experience, gouache has a pretty brutal learning curve, because it never "sets" even after it dries, so if you have too much water on your brush, you can easily reactivate it and have it bloom, mix, lift off, or turn into mud.

This also limits your layering because a lot of fresh wet paint over dry paint will reactivate the old paint and turn it into soup. So, if you make a serious mistake, it's better to wipe it away and repaint that area, than to try and paint over your mistake. Fortunately that's pretty easy to do.

On the plus side, provided you're working on decent paper, you have basically endless opportunities to correct your mistakes, and the opacity of the paint will cover up any stains left on the paper from earlier attempts.

To me, the most important thing is to control the amount of water in your brush; too much water and it makes a mess, too little and it won't go on smoothly. I have also trained myself to step away and let areas dry before adding another layer; otherwise they just mix on the sheet. Fortunately, this doesn't take long.

Also, every single paint will have a different consistency, from smooth to gooey, so you'll have to get used to that too. Some blues and greens get weird.

Once you get over that learning curve, though, gouache is really powerful and fun. There's a reason it was one of the defaults for commercial artists alongside acrylic, until computers took over.

I've attached one of my pieces so you can see my skill-level, and judge for yourself whether I'm worth listening to.
posts.filename: ROUND HOUSE PAINTED FINAL copy sml

>>6513630
I find it easiest of acrylic, gouache and water color. acrylic dries way too fast and you sort of have to do it all that session or waste paint. gouache can reactivate and come back to whenever. if i have to go do something else or the painting not coming together, i can just put lid on teh paint and come back the next day. very convenient. similar to water color but not as messy. can do wet layer or full opaque layer right away depending on what you want to achieve. as someone else said, you can mess up reactivating lower layers, but its hard to fuck up since you can just remove it or let it dry and paint over again since gouache so opaque you can literally just cover old layer with a single brush stroke if you dont water the paint down. lot of options. i recommend starting with it. pick up a himi jelly gouache set for cheap. comes with some brushes and pallet and all paint laid out for you in containers. i started with acrylic though, so had some knowledge of brush strokes, mixing, color theory, etc.

>>6517161
alright here's my advice, this is my advice to anyone starting on ebay.

larger inventory, wider variety of subjects, no auctions.

Auctions only work if you're selling antiques, or if you're one of the chadcels that started in 2001 selling and everyone on ebay knows you. Do Buy It Nows, with Offers on.

Otherwise just start cranking out as much art as you can, having 100 paintings to sell when you start is just better for you than starting with a few.

And try to improve doing it, that's key too, ebay gives you a chance to sell as you work and work as you sell. Really look at the data the website provides you to optimize keywords, figure out what types of paintings sell, try new things.

I wouldn't get worried about cost of shipping supplies because that's raw business stuff that you'll improve at the more you sell. It's hard to get the experience of cutting down on shipping costs and maximizing profits without first making profits. I remember early on I was shipping things for probably 3x what I should've been and lost most of the money from each sale just fucking up my shipping labels. That sucks, but it's unavoidable. That's just about learning how to run an online business. So for now just make as much of the best art you can, fiddle with prices, be communicative with buyers.

I have no advice for selling in Eastern Europe though, I have to charge American prices for things because everything here costs so much. If you could get your art to higher levels of quality there's no reason you couldn't sell to Americans and do vastly better than me, relatively speaking for your country.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6514403
ctrl+paint is good for what you want, don't take it too linear go to a video that peak your interest if you feel there are gaps in knowledge just go back and so on.
Some tricks that may help you in lineart but aren't covered on ctrl
-play with round and square tip brushes, I like square/rectangular better for line art.
-for tricky lines that overlay you can create a tmp layer draw the line you want erase what you don't need and then merge both.
-there's a layer mode called eraser what ever you draw on it will be erased on layers below in a non destructive manner
-instead of using pen pressure from 0 to 100% play with narrower ranges like 60 to 100% its easier to control while keeping line weight.

Small tablets aren't best for drawing/painting if you can get a used one that is medium, there's no need for a screen one yet as you go on you will know the time to get one, before I got my screen one I just sketched on paper take a photo and keep working on it with a screenless tablet.

>>6514499
>but he inkerd them befor that to make it easier to get a clean lineart by playing with the levels
Inking before scanning is just to make it easier, but you can get great results with just normal a pencil. You need better lighting, try using an external source of light, it most be even and a little softer (a piece of paper is great to soften the light), the settings of the camera/app would be something like wb:fluorecent, iso 100 and ev around 0.7, take the photo parallel to the page to avoid any warping.

>any place were I can see a project in action to get a better grasp of them?
most of the things I mentioned are applied here
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E0hGefr79AE

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6511119
Outside of Christianity (and possibly even then), religious art only works if you're into what you're making with some sincerity. People like collecting artwork of deities, ideas, talismans, and relatable experiences. I make a lot of them with the intention of being worn or to decorate an altar / sacred space. I sell both online and locally, but you could do well by just selling online. The biggest part that you would need to remember is that people will absolutely talk to you about your process, moreso than any other art. Your experiences are a bigger part of the selling point than you'd expect from other niches. If you say you aren't religious/spiritual and you were just making it for fun, they'll steer you into thinking you were touched or possessed, so it's better to nail down your narrative, real or fake. This is because they treat this art as an expression of God, and the market is always hungry for new work. It's the niche where I've seen art valued on a visceral level, and probably the only niche where AI won't replace anyone and settle in as a tool of surrealist visions.
Christian art requires more distance from coom, as I'm sure you'd imagine. I do have Christians who buy my stuff, but they're moreso from the mysticism or multi-path background. You can have thousands of religion and spirituality-based artists, but they all will do well as long as they're persistent because there needs to be art that caters to every personality.
It's probably the easiest niche to do well in, but the hardest to maintain because you'll need a spiritual connection of your own, or a good masquerade.

If an outcome has consequences, it can never be said to be zero sum, even if similar ends can be reached by different means. And we have it by the collective experience of thousands of generations. One of the mental traps people subscribe to these days is thinking you need any depth to avoid the infinite destructive contrivances of the world. There's nothing new in human nature, lust is still lust, violence is still violence, pride, jealousy, etc. It just so happens the wise answer to all these is just as simple as it is profound. Always has been. Just as some will always think they know better, some will always have to question, and others will see the logic in the wisdom and follow it.
Offering wisdom, like maybe you don't want to get aids from a hooker, or take your chances getting mugged/ shot by a pimp, or wind up face down in a Philly ditch from fentanyl- these are due diligence, and a product of care. It's just negligence otherwise.
Down to the little things, life is made of choices, your literal neurons are strung together according to what you do. Even a small guilt of hurting someone robs you of just that much more contentment, destroys that much more faith in yourself, and by proxy in others, and also following a higher ideal. Unless your ideal is to feel nothing, to be perfectly sociopathic, why would you purposely incorporate more than that which you will get naturally? But that's just cowardice isn't it, if you're not already? The converse option, of both holding the emotion and suffering through any downsides lands you more ability to enjoy it, and more strength to endure it. It's actual mental and social weightlifting. It's actually more exciting too, but I digress.

Draw stuff people want to commission and make yourself available. When you have a known brand what you draw and in what style, people into it are more likely to pick you up. Of course drawing well matters too, but not as much whether your stuff tickles the viewer's personal funny bone and if your art reaches their eyes. It does help to keep audience updated on your comm situation. Each time I close the comms, there's surge of new comms when I open them. Might be a good idea to give a few days heads up before opening the comms so potential clients are aware that you are soon available and they make the decision to comm you.

>>6520403

the answer to everytime you think "how do I get better at drawing anything"

Study the thing you want to draw better. download ref or make a pinterest board. save 1000 photos and draw them. You don't get good by just thinking about it. Draw draw draw and draw. Analyze every drawing, search for tutorials on drawing portraits. Never learn from just one teacher unless they're really good and you're paying for a 1 to 1 critiques. Use ref when you're making your own art. It's okay to use ref. It's not okay to copy ref 1:1.

if you got extra $$ and serious about this subscribe to an online class. Schoolism seems good and affordable.

>>6520879
There's no precise equation for pricing, but the factors are popularity of the artist, demand for his work, the niche he is catering to and the time spent crafting the thing. As these factors increase in value, so does the commission pricing.
You can do commissions whenever you want to, but by rule of thumb, you start when they ask you to produce something for them. Otherwise you look desperately hungry for money.

posts.com: The answer to this for most creative jobs is to make stuff. What do you naturally gravitate towards? Make lots of example work, show the sketch through to finished piece workflow, show some variations of silhouettes, colour schemes, values. And then only post the best 6-12 pieces. And apply, that's your portfolio. You might only start with small gigs, maybe you'll rely on twitter and upwork for experience, and unless you want to stay at the level you're at you should also expect and train to keep improving.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6512951
I don't know if you're trolling, but I somewhat agree. It depends on what you mean by construction. The Loomis head is a fine way to *understand* the construction and proportions of the head but it's too difficult for beginners to draw correctly in any but the simplest views, and too much unnecessary work for experienced artists. This is how I feel about most of what's called "construction." Simple shapes and guidelines are useful. Visual mnemonic devices are also helpful. For drawing from imagination, it's easier and more practical to remember, "The head from the front resembles an egg turned upside down" than to carve out some complex 3D wireframe that contains lots of information not even pertinent to the view being drawn. Of course, you have to have internalized the proportions, planes, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6512970
Even Loomis himself confuses things. See picrel from "Fun with a Pencil." The latitudinal line running around the ball is curved as if the ball is being seen slightly from above, but the longitudinal line is drawn as if we are at eye level with the center of the ball. If we were actually viewing the ball slightly from above, the "spit" running vertically through the ball would come down somewhat and be seen inside the outline, and the curve of the longitudinal line would be different.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It was probably Kodama Naoko. Not because her art but just the story telling.
I wasn’t ever really that into art growing up since my sister always mogged me so I didn’t even try to get into it. But I always loved reading.

Getting in manga in my late teens and finding some of Kodama’s manga was really eye opening to me. It’s just really touching and showed me there’s a world of story telling out there that just felt so much more vivid and lively than that of words on a page. And it really made me want to become a manga/comic artist so that I can tell stories of my own that feel as emotional and vivid as hers.

I’m still a long way from getting there but I feel like recently I’m feeling like I can transition into comics without feeling so overwhelmed.

posts.com:
I started learning jazz recently, and I learned about how they learn and how it transfers over to drawing. Turns out, those who learned to play by ear and didn't know theory, almost always were high class players, professional pianists. The students who learned the most theory, but never learned songs by ear, almost always sucked.

So yeah, draw a lot, don't worry about theory, and you'll be good at drawing automatically. Erroll Garner couldn't read music, but he defined jazz piano for the next 100 years.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The most important drawing skill is unaided observational sketching. I mean that as your ability to simply draw from observation in one fell swoop - no measuring, no proportion guidelines, no autistic angle comparisons, no excessive abstractions to see the subject as a series of nonsense shapes, no adjusting until it looks right. Just drawing rapidly with a high degree of accuracy.

This doesn't mean when making a portrait you shouldn't use all of those techniques, or that when drawing a meant-to-be-finished piece you shouldn't nitpick it as much as you please. I just mean that in terms of overall improvement potential, the person who has the ability to quickly observe and effortlessly sketch will be able to complete more, and better, studies in a shorter period of time than those who have to really put forth great effort to draw from observation. It carries over to efforts to drae from imagination as well - the man who can copy Bridgman with 80% accuracy by way of quickly executed sketches will complete the study in a few days with fewer barriers between his observation and understanding, while the guy who has to carefully plan, observe, and measure in order to reach maybe 60% accuracy might take many weeks, if he ever finishes at all, and at some point the intent becomes lost as he resorts to brute-force copying, the images he's observing becoming the observational equivalent of hearing a word repeated too many times - images without meaning. The first guy is left with a clearer, better memory of the whole of what he copied and can therefore better carry it over to his own work, while the second guy is left with a pile of drawings that were ultimately an effort of labored copying as opposed to actual learning.

I think the important thing that some people overlook is that studying fundamentals and working on raw observational work shouldn't be done to the exclusion of drawing from imagination and working on your personal projects. I saw somebody equating this to somebody who wants to run hyperfocusing on studying ideal gait mechanics and whatnot instead of just going out and running. Sure, you might be great at doing your studies and at some level know what you should be doing, but it takes time and effort to have your studies really stick and show through in your original work. Look at Proko, the guy can make some great stuff when engaged in careful observational work, but when it came to applying his knowledge through creative drawing and cartooning, he immediately struggled (though I think he's since worked on this). Regularly drawing what you want, especially from imagination, helps to keep your studies contextualized as feeding your knowledge base for your original work ("studying these female gymnast photos will help me draw my fit comic book heroine in stable, dynamic poses") as opposed to studies for the sake of studies ("yes, my copy of this image which happens to be a photo of a female gymnast is about 75% faithful to the reference; next time I will try to boost it to 80%").

ok anon I'm a beg (picrel a sketch from some 38 days ago and an attempt at a hard edge painting just so you can judge my advice based on my work) but if I may try and give some advice:
>Should I do them all probably right?
This feels like a kind of hyper-ambitious planning many people here, including me, are guilty of having done but realistically it usually doesn't work out and I think you will agree with me that it's a very big task and my advice would be to just choose one, see it through and then decide where to go next.
>8 hours at most isn't nearly enough time to explore something that takes like a year on DAB
I only went through the first few lessons of Peter Han's course, so again take my advice with a grain of salt, but the point isn't to master it all in 8 hours, the point is for him to give you the theoretical knowledge in each lecture and then for you to practice applying it by yourself afterwards before you move on and then throughout the whole course, going back to and refining concepts you've learned earlier.

My advice would be to choose one course that you feel drawn to, preferably one that's touted as good and by a good teacher, and then go at it fully. Don't just watch the lectures, find your own references and try drawing from imagination, too, practice is important.

In general, I think you should also do timed practice, here are some of the websites I've found nice, you can choose a timer and then you get automatically served different kinds of photos - there's people, hands, feet, heads, animals, plants and buildings
http://sketchdaily.net/
https://quickposes.com/en/gestures/timed

What has helped me the most was the start of Vilppu's Drawing Manual (I didn't get too far kek) and Hampton's Figure Drawing - learn to see curves and forms and to work with and draw gesture (use the 30 and 60 second timers on the above websites to practice this), a gesture is the building block on which you then plaster forms to create anatomy.

>>6511803
alright if DAB resonates with you then do that, from what I've seen of the course much of it focuses on construction and is quite technical in some aspects so I would recommend you do general gesture and non-construction sketching at the same time too

choose one of the sites I'd linked or a different one and do batches of 30 and 60 second drawings of humans, animals, bodyparts and whatever else they have here, you want to be able to quickly jot down the main lines of a "thing" instead of having to rely solely on detailed construction, especially when sketching (later you can do the construction to get everything looking absolutely right and correct after having your initial sketch done)

ofc go above 60 seconds, but 30 and 60 are good for learning to do stuff asap which forces you to learn to see and use only the main lines instead of getting lost in the details

and of course don't forget to keep drawing for fun, if it starts feeling like a slog to even get started drawing for the day then just draw whatever else comes to mind, having fun and staying engaged is the single most important part - the more you enjoy drawing, the more you will (ideally) draw and in the end that's what moves you forward, don't fall for the endless grind meme
best of luck anon!

>>6490932
As someone who went through a good chunk of DAB, I would say that the only worthwhile portion of it is that it is critiqued. The shitty part is that he intentionally tries to filter people with the 250 box/250 cylinder challenges and shit.
His method is "grind it out until you figure it out". I don't agree with that approach. I believe in understanding what you draw and refining that over time.
He has some good tips and tricks, for sure. Some of his perspective stuff is relatively good and accessible for most.
But focusing so much on constructive drawing without the rendering actually hinders your progress. In order to truly understand form, you have to understand how light interacts with it. If you know what you're doing, you can use lighting/shadow to completely change the form of your subject. You don't get that in this course.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6521561
this one is though, there are but not in the way you think. There are 2 ways you can tackle this:
1. use researchgate, google scholar, etc and use the keywords related to art, perspective, composition, color space, figure drawing, after finding something that interests you search it on scihub. What you might find is a bunch of computer vision papers and intensive on linear algebra, not really worth it unless you want to implement the proposed algorithm.
2. search filters on GMIC and look up papers for the filter you like, quadtree variants is a favorite of mine for example.

But I think what you are looking for is some kind of art philosophy instead of art math, robert henri the art spirit while not philosophy I think you will like it.

posts.com: How do you decide where a story should be told? Have you ever had second thoughts about your comic? Should it be a movie, a book, an album... How the fuck do you decide something like this?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6521574

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6521574
There are formal and practical considerations on considering your medium.
Formal involves how the story should be told. I enjoy comics because it's a balance between words and pictures. Film & animation wash over the viewer, with little participation needed. If audio is vital then obviously comics is ruled out (unless it can be worked into a webcomic).
Practical comes down to time and budget. Comics is the most accessible in this regard, no need to hire a team, actors, etc. The auteur approach is much easier in comics since one person can control all aspects of production. You can easily self publish online, vs.production is more difficult in things like film.
Books like related help in these matters. Once an artist is over fundies, it's time to think more deeply about things like medium, storytelling, content, form, etc.

Your mindset should be "whatever it takes". Reference photos to help with details and colors, 3D models to establish big shapes, perspective grid to start drawing details in. Organics and small objects can be freehanded, the big objects are what matters (pic related, by Shinji Kimura).

If you want to sketch and have fun then you can do it however you want to, but if you want the kinds of things that you see in anime movies and manga, you're going to be drawing for several hours and you need to give yourself every advantage you can. Use every tool available.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6516837
Systems. Its just about systems, or i guess guidelines is the more appropriate term but i prefer to think of it as systems. Anyway, you just create a few guidelines for yourself to follow and you try to be precise within those guidelines e.g. The road in that pic is a vehicle (no pun intended) for other elements to attach themselves to. Its a single curved plane heading towards the horizon, and anything on top of that road will have to naturally conform to it, thus the cars change direction in lockstep with the road.

Obviously use reference wherever you can to lessen the work load, but if you are doing backgrounds with many objects in them and you somehow cant find an appropriate reference, working within some guidelines you can easily understand is a good substitute. past that its just doing whatever makes sense to you personally.

posts.com:
>>6500480
depends if you are practicing right or just mindlessly get it done mentality etc. if you dont actively do anythign to improve and just repeat osme exercise you arent really sure why you are doing, you obviously wont improve even after hundreds of hours. if you slow down and analyze your practice exercises and actively look for mistakes and correct them, then you should improve.

for example, if you are doing ellipses or line weight or feathering/crosshatching and just scribble lines, thats not accomplishing anything. you are finishing the exercise, but its the same mistakes as the day before. you just wasted 15 minutes doing it or whatever.

when im in portrait mode, i'll do loomis heads from free references and full construction, etc. takes about half hour to do a head or two, depending on angle/difficulty/if i render it at all. the point is i am focusing on measurements, anatomy and actively measuring and trying to improve my portraits and construction. i'm not just filling a page with doodle heads and calling it practice. sometimes ill do the literal loomis plates.

practice makes perfect, but practicing wrong will always be wrong.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: So when it comes to drawing from life, is it best to break the subject down into simple shapes/forms and then "draw what you see"?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6508095
It's best, no a necessity, to start with blocking the drawing in the space of your canvas/paper. Measure from top to bottom, left to right and do a sort-of connect the dots lines to block the general "shape" your drawing will take up. Once your done with that and know for a fact that no part of the model's head/limbs will be cut outside of the canvas then you move in with large free strokes that give you the feeling of the pose and it's gesture. It is best to make them with your shoulder/elbow. It really doesn't matter what the subject matter is, a couple of cans have a line of placement and so-on. THEN you start breaking the subject/model into simple shapes on top of the free lines and IN the confined space you mapped in the begging.

>>6506347
>what's the correct resolution for 1000x1000 pixels?
1000x1000 pixels is always going to be 1000x1000 pixels, no matter what value you put in dpi, it wont add or remove pixels from your image, you can always change it afterwards, its information for printing, it only make sense if you have physical dimension too. for example 210 x 297 mm (a4 print size) printed with 300dpi, you will need roughly 2400x3500 pixels image to print it that way, but if you want to print lower quality 150dpi at same a4 size then you only need around 1200x1700 pixels image.

>>6506347
Senseless question. Understandable, because no one seems to know what that means, but it's easy.

The resolution is a value only useful for the printer. This value can be even deleted; in this case, the printer will assume a default value.
A resolution of 254 means that 100 pixel are equal to 1 centimeter.
A resolution of 100 means that 100 pixel are equal to 1 inch.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I started up drawing recently (< 2 months ago), and currently trying to understand how do I get proportions in human body right.
My approach is quite mechanical in nature, as in I either sketch from photos, or do rough sketches from imagination and then approach them with ruler to check, if I got proportions correctly.
Question is - perhaps there's some other method to that, and if so, can someone point me to that?
Any general advice on the matter is also appreciated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6513012
its usually relative to the head size. you can adjust proportions on head heights as well if you want someone heroic looking or for fashion designers they use like 10-12 head height and super long legs - but it would all be relative to the size of the head you draw.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i8CSKor2GNw is a fashion designer showing how to adjust a normal reference to a 10 head size. she discusses head heights, relative anatomy markings that coincide with the head heights, etc. you may not want to do fashion, but its still basically the jist of this.

but generally, youll have head heights for your character and then adjust proportions based on that. this doesnt change anatomy per se, but how they look when drawn. super heroes are like 8 heads usually, fashion croquis are 10-12, etc. children have different head proportions due to large heads/small bodies/still developing if you are doing children.

da vinci virtruvian man is probably most famous proportions image and it shows off a lot of basic anatomy and reference marks. ive attached a generic image of head heights though.

for the landmarks, 1 head is jaw to top of head. 2 heads usually hits at the nipples or around there (hanging breasts, muscled pecs, etc might put nipples above or below the line). 3 heads is usually hitting the belly button. 4 hits the crotch. the legs usually where adjustments are made for total head height proportions (8 for 'ideal/heroic', 10 for fashion, etc with longer legs for more heads). 5 is probably mid thigh, 6 the knees, 7 high ankle, and 8 would be the bottom of feet.

other landmarks can be learned. for instance, the wrists hanging at side hit just below crotch or deltoid lines up with nipples, elbows at belly button, etc. things like reilly rhythms teach more advanced relationships and lines that can help map out the way a body connects.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=djHcqOjAaoY does loomis body and discusses it with landmarks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6514014
just master studies and analyze their art. what do they do that makes it unique. like pen and ink you can look at so many options. thickness of lines. do they crosshatch or is it all hatches. do they obey perspective or do they only obey contours. do they use pure black and white or is there a wash or other greytone from diluted ink, etc. thats just the technical inking part on how they generate the lines. what they render and how they render it comes in.

for colored pieces, the color pallet is a large factor on top of the medium. a water color piece vs gouache or copics. a muted pallet vs vibrant ghibli poster paint style piece. ghibli or old disney cartoon style, for example, can be applied to any real world reference if you understand the simplifying of plants and basic colors used. very easy to study and learn as a simple example.

its not so much just 'copy' them as understanding what you are copying and why they draw or color or do the things they do. why did they crosshatch that. why did they dry brush that part only. why are they using such a dark pallet, etc.
