Many people suck on Jung Gi and many mangaka for their inking skills, but I got a question. I like my art either clean when working with ink, I don't like random scratchy lines. The thing is, I'm tired of having to repeat my strokes when working in digital. I see many modern mangaka doing these clean and stylish lines, even in hentai, and considering they work on a schedule, I do wonder how do they manage to do these.
Is it the tablet or what? I've had this one since 2017, it's one of those budget intuos from 2015. If it is, what practices can I implement to produce clean lines faster?
And, I mean, the tablet is very good for paintings and such, but when doing comic-like art I become very sluggish, and that is particularly frustrating because when going back to trad, lines come off flawlessly and quick.
What can I do?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Not a critique in particular, but some of the experiences I’ve had have made it to where I can’t trust anyone or my own opinions on my art.
I started off doing 3d stuff when I was getting into art. I would think the things I made looked ok and I would post them and get mixed responses. I would later look at the things I made and realize that they did indeed have some serious issues.
I can’t trust a compliment because it may be insincere, I can’t trust myself because my ability to judge my own work is inconsistent and I don’t know what good art is supposed to look like anymore, I can’t trust insults because I don’t know if someone is trying to spite me or be honest, I can’t trust a critique because of the same reason I can’t trust a compliment or an insult
I started getting into art because I wanted to make indie games, and I wanted one or a few games to have character designs that look like Urbosa because I like Urbosa, but her design has a niche appeal and because of that and because I can’t trust myself, I look at the things I make and feel as if I don’t know what they look like.
I’ve been getting into drawing recently and gotten some compliments on some things on other websites, but some of the people complimenting me seem as if they’re even less aware of how their own art looks that I don’t even know if I’m getting anywhere.

>>6518732
Here's an actual critique of that drawing.

Your character is not drawn in any sort of perspective. Limbs are elongated oddly, joints are misshapen, bones are rotated 90 degrees halfway down their length.

Your line weight is all over the place. It doesn't look intentionally ragged, it just looks ragged.

The forms you are trying to describe come across as flat, with little to zero dimentionality. The lines indicating folds in cloth don't appear to wrap around limbs, making it hard to read them as folds.

The gesture of your character is weak. There's no settled pose, yet there's no clear action either. It feels unnatural because that body position is unnatural, especially the left leg.

Remember, appeal is everything. There can be appeal in the ugly, I'm not saying your character needs to have DD tits and wide hips, I'm saying you have to improve in order to get good at making appealing art, in order to learn how to make appealing ugly art.
What are your goals? You clearly place a huge amount of personal meaning into these drawings, so why are you posting them? You must be aware that the average person will shit on it, which will hurt you directly. You should not stop drawing these things, but I would recommend you stop posting them, because you're just going to be a punching bag. If you want feedback on your drawings, draw a subject you don't care about, and draw that instead. Better yet, try to do studies of great pieces and break away from your "style".
Get the hell out of that comfort zone, dude.

Also, I am lonely. I don't have anyone to talk to most of the time and drawing is my only real hobby besides vidya. That's all really.
I know it's kind of annoying when people say they "draw for themselves" but I really do. I want to improve HOW I draw but not necessarily WHAT I draw, changing what I draw defeats the point of drawing in my mind. I'd rather everyone chew me out for having disgusting characters they dislike than create something that doesn't have a part of my soul in it. And when I do find people who like my art it feels really nice.
>You must be aware that the average person will shit on it, which will hurt you directly
I'm aware but I am also extremely socially stunted and this thread kinda threw me for a loop. I don't even really interact with people online so I thought More people would get it? But clearly I am wrong.
>break away from your "style".
For why?

Feel retarded for being this way and I think it is childish to most people, like I'm supposed to have a more grand goal or more consumable style.

>putting them in a setting
This is what I have been working on, story, and I really need to fucking draw BACKGROUNDS and put everything together but it is a slow and gruelling process it's so exhausting. But I think i'll get there.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6518872
>for why?
Break away from your style and draw something else because doing so will force you to learn by throwing the unfamiliar at you. As you expand your scope of work you will see direct improvements in the stuff that is meaningful to you.
Also, you will make more friends sharing your practice drawings and learning and growing than you ever will by posting the same skill level of drawings of characters which have immense importance to you but to everyone else (not just 99%) have no meaning.
Remember, everyone has gone through tragedy, everyone has felt alone, everyone has felt frustration at themselves if not full blown hate for being socially awkward.
Listen, I care enough about you from a basic level as a himan being to give you this advice. If you take it, and run with it, and decide that you are going to avoid trying to make every drawing meaningful, and instead make the effort to draw a variety of things and learn where you are weak and train yourself to be stronger, then I guarantee that at least 1 person will like you more than they do now. You'll also start getting real feedback from many more anons, especially if you have a positive attitude.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Something very similar to you OP
I started at 12, pretty much by drawing pokemon
It started out of boredom, pulled up a picture of a Torchic and started drawing it , after that I became hooked to the point that I ended up drawing 181 out of the 700+ pokemon there were back then

Anyway, since there were so many drawings, tons of paper, they were impossible to hide obviously, and my bigger sister found them.
She started laughing and mocking me, and started laughing even more after she found the list of the pokemon I was planning to draw later on

It was not a one time thing, it turned into harassment after she would stop mocking me about the pokemon thing even when I was just doing homework or whatever

I went crying to my mom and told her what was happening, she pretty much didn't care and did nothing. I quit.

I'm simplifying the experience a lot to avoid writing even more than this.

At 13-14 I tried to get back into it, but what i discovered is that thanks to that experience I couldn't draw if there would be people around, if I tries i would feel fear and some kind of anxiety (?, It was a hard to explain feeling. So I could only draw when there was nobody around, Wich was almost never.
Anyway I still have that anxious feeling, but I've been able to get back to it since now I go to university and there's a few places that are desolated

As a curious detail, at some point I started getting into drawing people after discovering "Gijinka" (pic related)

I hate pokemon now btw, not the games themselves, but the memories associated.

Btw2, you may think i was a pussy yeah, but I was only 11-12

I hope its coherent what I said.
t. Spic

>>6521510
"anatomy for sculptors" Book by Sandis Kondrats and Uldis Zarins is very thorough with plenty of references and is usually what I see everyone use for properly studying anatomy.
Medical books are very sterile and always are focused on remembering the muscles technical uses and names rather than their visual look.
There's a thread called /sqtddtot/ - Stupid Question Thread where a question like this would be more welcome. This doesn't need a thread really.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6521510
paul richers artistic anatomy has dons of very detailed illustrations, strength training anatomy by frederic delavier is another good one, also classic human anatomy by valerie winslow. That should keep you busy for a while.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My Personal favs are: Stephen Rogers Peck (very useful to go with Bridgman) Elliot Goldfinger a classic with every single bone and muscle from front side and back and then also photos of how they're all togetther and with skin on top, Stonehouse anatomy a big ass book with 650 pages of content choke full of information on what's the functionality of each piece using some humor so it doesn't get too much of a burden.

I think I'll go with Peck for the Practical puposes since Vilppu and Bridgman got you covered on how to draw the figure. But judging from what you want based on your comment I think you're looking for Stonehouse, the 3 of them are easy to find on .pdf to download, if you can't find them write me and I'll search them for you.

Sarah Simblet is very visual but the point of that one is to actually buy it since the anatomy are transparent and on the other page there's a person so you can place it over to see how everything gets placed.

Reading all these parents horror stories makes me wonder about mine...
My parents initially adviced me to not get into commissions because it was too alien and seemed too risky to them, so it took me being reckless and not listen to them for me to start with commissions a few years later.
They are just happy for me making money with my stuff, but regarding the money itself, they are very hesitant, like they dont want to have anything to do with my finnances (outside advicing me how to spend my money wisely); at the same time they seem to expect me to willingly hand them some money to cover family spending, I do it when it is most needed because we're just the three of us and all money we get is used to sustain each other as family, it would be scummy of me to not help.

They are kind of proud of me, I guess, and Im the only child of the three in our household that doesnt get bitched at for job/money related issues... cousin A gets bitched at for not sending my aunt money on a basis despite living in another, wealthier country, cousin B gets bitched at for not doing well at his jobs and also barely being of help.
All that makes me wonder... did I get lucky or it's just a matter of time for me to get bitched at in one way or another? I think the whole issue is calm because...
1. My money is insignificant enough to be of any real weight (except in dire days)
2. Im actually being employed by my father in the family business, so it's not like Im not doing anything but drawing/college

Will things get inevitably worse when I get more money and/or live on my own?

>>6517416
>how do you fucking draw
You're doing it, this is good practice. The cup on the first page looks great, aim for that level on all the others. If you're having trouble moving past this step my advice would be to focus on your accuracy and quality. The angles of the edges, the wobbly lines, the actual way the cup handle looks, they're all examples of weak technical skill holding you back. >>6517426 is a good question that would help people here guide your practice, but since we don't know, I can only assume these drawings are what you want to improve.

So -- slow down, check your angles before you draw lines, and draw those lines light and as straight as you can. You should know where the line ends before you draw it. If you're having trouble with angles then take the picture into an image editor and trace over them, tracing is a great tool to check for errors. Do whatever it takes to get a high quality image on the page, consistently. If you mess up just draw the same object again.

>>6517494
As long as you're doing deliberate practice - that is you have a standard up to which you're measuring yourself - you will improve as long as you keep practicing. I found it helps drawing from life for this reason: you can see and compare, find what you did wrong, and re-try if you have the energy.
The fact that your brain is telling you that you're not doing great right now is a good sign. This constant evaluation of relative successes and failures is what will eventually engrave successful methods and approaches in your long-term memory.

Continuing this sort of construction without CARE won't lead to (much) improvement, but it will give you mileage. If you constantly let your errors go without retrying or self-correcting then you won't learn anything. Imagine if a math student thought 2 plus 2 equaled 5 and told the teacher "I don't want to learn the right answer." Pushing through hard objects and holding yourself accountable to mistakes is where the learning and improvement happen.

i see myself in op's pic and i dont like it.

you chicken scratch a lot. measure 10 time and draw once. ghosting lines from drawabox taught me that. also connect dots. that also helps.
learn to hold pen properly and draw with whole arm. wrist, elbow and sholder. mostly elbow and wrist. hand should not rest on paper but can touch it for more resistance and control. drawabox and some others taught me that.
no perspective. cant draw stuff in 3d if dont know perspective. norling and scott robertson taught me that read them i guess. norling is easy. robertson is technical and hard.

idk if this helps. good luck.

hello, are you the anon from beg who decided to try out evistons book: art and science of drawing? if yes then forgive me, despite me being know for mass replier i didnt manage to (you) your post due to fatigue.

Anyway if you are fresh beg then all your lines will be wobbly by default simply because you dont have enough kilometers in your hand. You probably want to redo the basic exercises like in my pic related.

Anyway the book said first to envision the line, then "draw it" holding the pencil few millimeters above the surface of paper and then while doing the motion to gently lower the pencil and make very thin barely visible line. And after you are happy with the shape you then take your sharp B pencil and make thick bold line finalizing the contours.

From what i can see you arent doing this. Redo the previous chapters. Other than this there isnt any magical advice, you just need to keep drawing and pywing in /beg until anons start popping up and telling you that you are on right track or that you have improved.

Let me cite the very book you are at now
>have realistical expectations about the learning curve
Personally i found drawing basic bitch items like books or cups incredibly hard and frustrating, try something more fun like fruit or tanks (which you are recommended to draw in next chapter anyway).

good luck and patience anon, you gonna need it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6518774
>go over the line multiple times
sure, but in barely visible thin light lines so that you dont compromise the final art output. And after the proportions, symmetry and shape meets desired outcome you are supposed to make solid confident dark line to finalize the contour. Are you using correct pencil? You should have at least two: one hard (H) and one very soft (B with high number). Experiment which one you like better for sketching. For final outline you want to use the B because it can produce dark tone easily.

In your pic i can see the sea of lines and none of them is final. this is easily making your output way worse for no reason.

And feel free to pick more interesting things to draw and practice on. Shoes, tanks, cars, houses, castles, guns... its as the book said, almost all man made objects are basically just spheres and cubes.

Eyes
Feet
Neck

In that order. If you're doing an eye patch, draw the eye first then the patch over the top so you don't end up with a figure that looks like it has a genetic disorder. The hem of the stockings, waist and general perspective etc is good, you've got potential.

Yeah don't follow the losers at this board. They are nobodies who will not gonna make it. I am a pro and work as concept artist. posts.com:
>>6519627
All those things are reasonable things to try, but depending on how much of a beginner you are, even trying to do one of these might be too taxing, take too much time and be too discouraging. There's a reason a lot of beginners do floating heads: that's what they have the patience for.

Why not aim for something, and try to strategically make incremental steps towards it? What is it that you most want to do, that motivates you to want to draw in the first place? If you can't do that, what incremental steps could you imagine leading to that? (And if not, what would be an incremental step to that? etc.) Then you can make a program with incremental progression, that makes you feel motivated to come back to drawing, instead of "I have to do X because past me said so."

I think a good place for beginners to try to work towards is 3 hours / 5 days a week. There are diminishing returns, with more hours per day spent, but I think that even beginners can benefit from that. But if you can't do that, start with what you can do. 1 hour, even a half hour spent on your own is a worthy start.

>not really
If you split your time relatively evenly and once you account for transitions, you're spending just 15 minutes on a subject per session. Outside of a session of timed gesture drawings, that's hardly enough time to meaningfully internalize what you're drawing/copying, particularly if it's accompanied by reading, watching tutorials, finding good refs, etc. If you can already draw super quickly and accurately and already have a moderate understanding of the topics, then alright, maybe 15 minutes is enough to work on bolstering your understanding and gaining mileage. But if you're coming in as a beginner, you should spend more time on studies and internalizing as opposed to trying to cram in so much shit so quickly.

Here's how I've seen AI used to create concept art
>upload rough sketch of character
>copy/paste prompts from document file
>have AI generate hundreds of images
>go through each image and pick out aspects that you like
>clip/paste to create composite image in photoshop
>upload composite image
>move sliders
>repeat process until you have a wholly generic piece of bland concept art
There's no time being saved using AI, and the results are underwhelming for the time spent to generate the image.

AI is shit and will more than likely ruin a piece, contort it away from your intentions due to limitations of AI.

The best use is not completing a piece but showing you routes to take should you come across a block. It might add details you could implement by your own hand, give a better aesthetic and style. It's good at rendering so may give you a plan to move forward.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428290
>It looks particularly bizarre to have the canvas and wood fins coming out of heavy iron/steel/whatever.
they are iron, on both of my designs, the lines are segments, but i can see why one could think they are made out of canvas
>also... why does it have regular ship screws?
because its also works as regular battleship if none of the anti gravitational fuel is available, the flight mode cannot be sustained forever too, because of the liquids properties (has to be kept at a certain temperature and mixture with gases to work/ overheating issues etc.)
>Show pipes or... something to differentiate from regular hull
i think its pretty distinctive from regular battlesip hulls, but i guess it could use more details, proruding pipes arent good for hydro/aerodynamics though., the fuel is highly explosive/hard to obtain aso it wouldnt be smart to have them visible, they are housed behind massive super thick armor plating behind the bublbs under the steering propeller arms, most of the magic is on the inside, like massive stabilising gyroscopes, special pipes and motors for the outside propeller gondolas.etc
also pic relatd are some earlier versions and a regular battleship

I'm assuming these are all from same person yeah?
I'd suggest more decisive lines, try to visualize what you want to put down before you do. Looks like you're familiar with drawthrough method obviously, but yeah there is some inconsistencies in the perspective, but the drawings major issue is the hairy lines, also once you have that down don't get lost in the details, make sure it still reads as the object intended from a distance. You could also try drawing some mechanical objects in a 3 point perspective and see how you do. Hope that helps although You've probably heard similar advice before

>>6458574
I was toying around with threads and I got it to look decent, though the perspective is off.
As for the texture, I made Triangle pattern and used the bend tool or w/e in Kirta since I was trying to see how it would look, trying to go for that camo netting pattern thats pretty hard to draw, In the end it was just a test, since I was learning about using textures and what not.
The hard part about the treads is that it it looks off if the perspective is off. It took me a bit to figure out how shade these and show that they are treads on the track, but you need a good underline or if not, dont strictly follow the underline if you know the perspective is off. I could fix it but I moved on for this until I get some coloring practice in.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Sorry to hear, dude. I'd help. Genuinely I would. My life is shit and I'm broke and lonely, but I've studied art for a long time and I have a handle on fundies. Not sure how we'd get in touch in this context though, and I fear I'm not the teacher type.

I will say that the most mileage i've gotten skill-wise has been doing life studies. Draw simple stuff on your desk every day. Helped me a ton. Also careful master studies , painting or drawing. Personal whatevers should be done in between studies. Get deep with a study then do a personal painting/drawing and then repeat.

Probably you should join a discord group if you can and try making connections there. I'm out of the loop with this shit but I hear there's good discord groups. Get out there and connect with enough people and get enough feedback and you're golden. I mean actually you probably shouldn't expect to be spoon fed stuff. What makes a great artist is the thinking they do on their own while picking apart this art thing. But everyone's different. A good tutor may genuinely be the ticket.

In any case, don't get discouraged and I wish you the best. I know its hard but considering you mention college, you're probably still pretty young. Don't be too hard on yourself and compare yourself to others too much.

If you're failing to grasp fundamentals despite practicing hmm...

Just like...draw THROUGH the form and really try to feel it. Break everything down into simple shapes and use the fewest marks possible. The key to good drawing and painting is being able to simplify. Learning to paint/draw is learning to see. Draw coke cans and stacked books on your desk and do 30 second gestures every day and legit copy by sight drawings or paintings by your heroes to get the feel for what they're doing.

Sorry for the novel but your post made me sad and I really hope you make it, anon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
OP, do you put in the hours DAILY?

I am a language teacher and the only students I have who make actual progress are the ones who stay in touch with the language.
I am not teaching them even 10% of what they're learning, I'm only giving them corrections, saying "you should try X and Y instead of Z" and then they go and do that for 6 days of the week, before checking back with me on the 7th.
These are the ones who pick up on all the small tips I give, because they actually try and experience the problems, and when I give them instructions, they are not something that they have to LEARN, it's more like something they have to THINK ABOUT, NOTICE, and then correct, at least most of the time.

Comparatively, I have began music lessons recently, as a complete beginner.
In 2 months I have made a huge progress because I practice every day for 1 hour.
While most students my teacher has don't do their homework and are forced to do it during class time, wasting 1 hour of everyone's time by repeating scales, I grind those scales at home, ask my teacher about the points I'm struggling with, he listens to my whining and gives some points. I probably only practice for 5 minutes during his class, everything else is discussing what I can do on my own to progress, DESPITE the fact that I'm a beginner and am at the stage where a lot of hand-holding is necessary.

As a non-beginner, handholding should be minimal, only at key elements.

If you can identify with the study ethics I described above and still think a tutor would be your solution, THEN the problem becomes finding a good one, because most teachers are there for beginners, who are the ones who need the most instruction.

One suggestion I can give if there's no one to be found, is to participate in collaborative projects. Find people working on something and offer a hand, socialize, or just compare how other people treated the same subject as you in their part of the work, you can learn a thing or two.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6514161
That's a tough one, I go through the same issue and having 4~6 hours of productivity a day is something I consider a successful day, I'm slowly building it up from there.
The first step is either fixing your sleep schedule or finding a routine that you can follow regardless of time, starting at the time you wake up. It's harder, but possible if you plan your meals and have flexible IRL obligations.

>>6514174
That has to do with the anon I was responding to above.
Learning to LIMIT your daily study is also very important to avoid burnout and inefficient practice.
If you feel like 8 hours aren't taking you anywhere, limit your practicing hour to 3 a day. And find something else you can do with those 5 hours. Maybe it's working on a project for 3 hours and watching some tutorials/taking CONSCIOUS notes for 2 hours.
Maybe it's making a study plan so you can grind the next day with the certainty that you are doing structured learning.

The biggest enemy of progress is being impatient, you have to trust the method and let time do its thing.
But trusting the method is a daily struggle, we want to improve NOW. That's why so many gurus are always shilling meditation, because people need to learn winding down is part of the process.

Here's a video on why you should limit yourself, and being productive isn't always good:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TImmiAS1USQ

Here's a course some anon recommended to me two years ago and I've followed through, implementing a few of the methods described into my routine to stop living life under constant stress and impatience:
https://www.coursera.org/learn/learning-how-to-learn

IMPORTANT: Applying these concepts. Going "Ah, makes sense" and not attempting anything is also bad. Don't be an information hoarder. Think less about what is OPTIMAL and think about what is CONSISTENT.

posts.com:
>>6514161
By doing something you want to do. If it's a struggle to do this for art, then reconsider your priorities.
Blog time: I was your typical "bright" kid in school who got the praise and as a result never learnt how to study or practice, hit the wall that you do in late high school and my grades tanked because I didn't know how to actually apply myself. I graduated and without really thinking about it just dove into drawing. Even though I was/am definitely not a "disciplined" person, I didn't need to be because I just did what I felt like doing. I didn't study, I only drew what I wanted and yet I improved and continue to improve because I'm actively making things and striving to improve.

Here's the bit that may be relevant to you: if you have to force yourself then is it even a good idea to pursue art? I feel like there's not much point in doing art if you find yourself having to force yourself to draw. I don't mean if you're already a pro artist or whatever and need to force yourself to draw more to meet deadlines, I just mean in these earlier stages where you have no dependence on drawing and are at the stage where you should be doing it because you like it and are deciding whether you want to pursue it further.

Work ethic is only really needed when what you have to force yourself to do something unpleasant. If you enjoy what you do then work ethic is not a skill you need to hone. It may still be useful, ie to make yourself work even when you don't want to, but when most of the time you want to do the work most of the time you won't need to exercise discipline to get it done.

>>6509559
Dynamic Sketching is a good course, but it was first developed as a subject on Art Center's illustration and Entratainment Design programs.

The thing is that there Prefessors can assume that students will be having other fundamentals courses at the same time. When it got ported to the internet, through CGMA, there was also a program there that expected you to have a good basis on perspective before going to Dynamic Sketching. (Check CGMA's Foundation & Design Track)

If you don't have that basis especially in perspective, and you are a bit older and so don't blindly trust an instructor but rather "want things to make sense" you'll feel exactly as you've described: not prepared for next steps.

You need a basis before moving on. For that I would recomend:

-Beginner's Guide to Art Fundamentals - Forest Imel (ArtStation)
-The Art and Science of Drawing - Brent Eviston (Udemy)
-Absolute Beginners - Yves Yumol (CGMA)
-Art-WOD's Beginner's Course - Antonio Stappaerts (Art-WOD)
-The Art and Science of Figure Drawing - Brent Eviston (Udemy)
-Essentials of Realism - Jonathan Hardesty (Schoolism)
-Beginner’s Guide to Drawing - Steve Huston, Chris Legaspi, Heather Lenefsky, Bill Perkins, Joshua Jacobo, John Asaro, and Mark Westermoe (NMA.art)
-Ctrl+Paint Free Video Library - Matt Kohr (Ctrl_Paint)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6514285
are you the same anon that wrote this roadmap once?

You are going to learn "the fundamentals" for your whole life. Getting a ton in the beginning since you start from nowhere and after you've made that basis learning more and more before you die eventually still unsatisfied and feeling you still had much to learn.

In that line the idead is that you know about the fundamentals in a overview way to know where you are getting yourself into before diving deep in it.

To that end watch: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ni4ts22XFsw AND https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ax130yILbw0&list=PLVgLT-e3jXPDgeED0pD0BPq8kY1VAZAGa

More on ABOUT THE FUNDAMENTALS (AND HOW TO PRACTICE THEM):
-Beginner's Guide to Art Fundamentals Full Series by Forrest Imel
-Fundamentals Course - A guide for starters in art by Hue Teo

DON'T do Drawing Fundamentals with Thomas Fluharty (Schoolism) it's AWFUL

Drawing Fundamentals Phase I & II aren't as bad but aren't as helpful either, since they pretty much just say: "that's what you should have already known before starting our program".

>I'd go the line of:
The Art & Science of Drawing > Absolute Beginners > Beginner Guide to Drawing > Essentials of Realism with Jonathan Hardesty > Art-Wod Beginner Course > Perspective by Marshal Vandruff > CGMA's FUNDAMENTALS of perspective (if you can find it) > DrawABox > The Art & Science of FIGURE Drawing > Dynamic Sketching with Patrick Ballesteros / Sorie Kim / Peter Han > Drawing Manual > Hot to Draw > Med's Map [It will have become available by the time you get to it.]

posts.com:
So here's the thing: the materials listed above are many times over what a beginner could need at the start as far as technique information goes. There will probably be more suggestions and useless discussion below but we all know that a person willing to take action can get over the beginning stages of art with a little time and these resources.
But what of the question on how you get yourself to spend time making art and practicing making art? Really, that is the bane of all the people who come here over and over again failing to make any real progress. A person determined to spend their lives drawing will maybe look at a few of these, choose some and spend a lot of time drawing taking in the advice. But why do anons fail to do so? They have some sort of motivation, but clearly it's not so much aimed at drawing or practicing itself, but rather at "becoming an artist" or "making it". If they wanted to actually draw they would do it. So what can be done about that? How does a person who aims at "becoming an artist" change their aim to "spending their time drawing"? Or how does one give up on it?
Honestly I'd love to hear your ideas but I feel like there's no real good answer here. Like if you could solve that even in 10% of cases you'd probably be rich as a teacher. Are anons just doomed to repeat their mistakes? Surely there's at lest a few of those that didn't aim for drawing itself that managed to change that. Maybe there's some common thread amongst them. Maybe it's just luck too.

>>6498614
I use a very tight 'precision' grip with my thumb,index and middle fingertips. I can only work on a single page or 2 a day maximum before it starts hurting.

The grip is so strong that when I put down the pencil there is a slight indentation on my fingertips from holding the pencil so hard. As expected, the paper gets pretty beat as a result.

I manage to mitigate this some by using a rubber grip or just putting a small piece of those kneaded rubber erasers around the area where I hold the pencil.

I honestly feel uncomfortable holding it in any other way.

I think it would be best if you drew in one of two ways, or both. Either keep the proportions you have but simplify them, make it more stylized and cutesy, or make their bodies bigger and find a way to compliment the folds.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6519952
I'll put in my two cents here.

I like the faces method in conjunction with the points method to check because that allows me to still get the proportion right while not worrying too much about the exact vanishing points right away. The face method is useful as Loomis shows you that like the cube, you can draw cross contour faces in addition to the top and bottom faces to figure out the exact form of any object once you connect them all up.

Unlike the other methods, if you train the faces method with points method as a guide you can easily transition to drawing organic things as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6519570
look for shapecarver's (scott flanders) stuff. he did concepts for evolve, has a podcast, and did some stuff for proko, I think. he explains things pretty well.

there are plenty of resources for learning about monster concepts, but it seems pretty straightforward. thumbnail sketching and designing silhouettes do seem to be the main first step for stuff like you said, but knowing a lot about anatomy (human and animal) is equally important. it helps to be kind of a biology nerd, I guess.

I wonder how I could transfer to silhouettes. I've always been kind of a constructionlet and just drawing. Seeing people do silhouettes is really confusing. It's like you have to know already the whole picture in your head accurately so you can just blop down it's "outlines" and work from there. I'm propably thinking about it wrong.
Though I think Peter Han also did very construction heavy sketches, but I don't know if he's an actual concept guy, or something else entirely.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: fzd on youtube

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6519652
construction is super important, but if you want stuff like shapecarver, it has to be more silhouette-driven imo. being good a construction seems very important for making it believable after you have a silhouette to seed your design with. shapecarver's stuff is just 3-4 flat values blocked in but you can tell he knows a lot about anatomy -- and interestingly it seems to be almost exclusively human-centric anatomy. it seems like if you want to start with something pretty abstract like silhouetting, you have to be pretty well versed in shape language and design principles like rhythm, repetition, big-medium-small, etc.

it looks like he's doing stuff with proko even pretty recently. he seems kind of loose and unassuming but he really knows his shit. I've seen him crit student work and he's got very strong fundies.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J8g3JKobvnk
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KdEoaTu8D38

>>6505190
I don't think the foreshortening really works with this image. One, his leg is in a very, very uncomfortable position for it to be twisting out towards the viewer as it is. Two, from a compositional standpoint, we tend to follow the gaze from a character in a piece toward whatever they're looking at. As he's posed, the line of his gaze is broken by his knee. It makes the composition feel a bit cramped and less interesting than it could be.

Personally, I would do something like this. Repositioning the legs gives some room in the composition to build up a more engaging scene with the environment. But ymmv.

>>6516603
The church wanted to control people, so desired art that depicted biblical events in realistic painting.
Asian art from the same period was more focused on telling folk tales and the stories of rulers, depicted in the same style as old historical art to enhance the mythos or whatever you'd call it. Plus the nature of woodblock printing which was a big thing in ancient Asia was more suited for simplistic and reproduceable depictions.
The west could've easily gone down the same path if instead of pivoting towards realism due to the church' they just kept doing the same old pre-renaissance paintings that came before them.
And also worthy of note is the notion of beauty that atleast Japan's case, which was a top priority when creating art for them, since realism was dirty and such.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Western art sucked for centuries, until they decided to gitgud.

The same would have eventually happened in Asia, it just so happens they had contact with the West before having the opportunity to come up with it themselves.

Same thing happens with bronze age and other important kingdom-forming technologies. Everyone was a bunch of apes shitting in the bushes, until some village figured out at random how to bend metal to its will.
In the grand scale of things, mankind did jackshit for millions of years, then struck up on this BIG discovery and completely changed in the span of 15.000 years.

Compared to the millions of years dillydallying, 15.000 years is not a lot, if we as a species only discovered this technology TODAY, the timeline of human evolution would look about the same. But because SOME people discovered it earlier than other, it gave them a huge advantage in conquering their neighbors and becoming king of the hill, forcing everyone else to sink or swim.

Either way I don't think it matters much who did what first because most of supposedly Ancient Chinese principles which later on impacted the rest of the Sino sphere aren't inherently Chinese. The biggest East Asian influences such as Lao Tzu's Daoist philosophies on dualism (same with Chinese alchemy) predate China and Buddhism is from Ancient India but Confucianism I'm not so sure where Confucius would have been inspired by. I also don't think there is a cohesive Chinese culture, it is not a monolith, it is constantly changing and historically it shows through constant civil turmoil. China itself is very ethnically diverse with many provinces having their own local culture and language and many different Chinese ethnic groups besides the Han. For example compare Beijing, Hong Kong, Yunnan, Sichuan, and Taiwan. So yeah, arguing what came first or what is what is kind of a meaningless task in itself because what's here now is already lost and irrevocably different from then.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Practice the mudras, copy them, get a good shape of the hand, make the fingers elegant, seek out unusual poses and expressions, copy as much as you can find.
When you can draw them in your sleep, get experimental with expressions, wilder with angles, and take some references from real life while keeping every detail in the rules of mudra-drawing.
When you are done with that, just forget how to draw the mudra. Draw a hand however it feels right.
This thing takes time. Enjoy the process. Or fuck off and waste your time somewhere else. Good luck, anon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6519007
Count how many things in your home are made of cloth. Draw them. Toss them on the couch and draw them again. Repeat.
Count how many things are made of metal in your home. Draw them. Pile them together with brightly colored objects and draw them. Repeat.
Draw naked people and learn to understand what gesture and anatomy are.
Once you understand drapery, figure drawing, and how light interacts with metallic objects, you will have some hope of drawing a character dressed in armor with some level of competence.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6518274
Your grip is all about mobility. Holding the pencil with the middle, ring and little finger curled in gives you the mobility of your hand. Fine for writing, terrible for art. Extending all four fingers gives you the mobility of your wrist which is good for sketchbooks. Holding the pencil overhand gives you the mobility of your shoulder, this is ideal for easel work. Everything else is practice.

an easy way to get black is by simply adding too much blue pigment. it's why cheap black ink appears blue when smudged, smeared or dripped.
yellow ocher, van dyke brown, the various reds/browns you get from varying amounts of iron oxide etc are all plant derived while most blues and purples are created artificially.

they'll do their best to create a consistent "feel" across pencils, leads, paints, pastels, etc but depending on how ornery and picky you are you may feel some difference.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6517920
Two reasons:

1. Assuming you aren't permanently glued to your computer then it's beneficial to carry a sketchbook with you to practice wherever and whenever. Drawing from life will help your observation skills and continuously build your visual library. It's a great habit to develop and you'll see improvements in your digital work as well.

2. (This one is not important if you don't care about it). Pen tablets are inherently disconnected in that what your eyes see vs what your hand does is not 1:1 matching, this means that if you only draw digital then you aren't building dexterity or coordination that you'll be able to use if you ever want to do trad. Leading to: "my digital drawings have been good but how come my pencil sketches always look like shit now?".

>>6518012
> guess i better get used to eraser shavings and buying scrapbooks fuck me
You could look into getting kneaded erasers, avoids the eraser shaving issue and they last a long time.

For sketchbooks go as cheap as you can for the medium you use. Standard sketchbook paper quality is usually fine for pencil or other dry medium as well as ballpoint pens which use oil-based ink.

You'll usually only have to spring for higher quality if you want to use copics/fountain pen ink or delve into wet mediums like watercolor for instance.

Enjoy the process, good luck.

When my mother died of cancer, in the last month, she almost regressed to a child like state, or at least I kinda saw her as a child and me the parent, and in that last month I felt a love that I never felt for her before, not with that intensity.
To live that kind of love again, or even greater is I think the greater purpose in life.
Life is about balance, you take some and you give some back, and the same goes for drawing and art in general, you take in life and you have the possibility to digest it through art, at least that's how I see it, and it doesn't have to be pretentious, just how you see things and feel them, nothing magical about it, everyone can do it.which is also what makes me especially sad about AI art in general, the fact that people are robbing themselves of themselves.
And since this is still supposed to be an artwork and critique board, here's a speedpaint I did a couple of months ago.
Sorry for the long rant.

posts.com:
>>6494108
Go for it man. I've studied with people who became successful artists starting at the age of 40 or 50, all the cynicism here is a meme. The field is hard but if you work at it and really think about the work you're doing and who it's for you can definitely find a niche.

The best advice I can give you is to try and find classes or studios by you. Just walk-ins for figure drawing, not an art school or anything like that. Self study can definitely work for some people but you'll always improve more efficiently if you're with a community and have people giving you live advice. Watching How to Draw streams and pirating art books is the fastest way to stagnate if you don't know exactly what you're doing.

Oh, i just paint where i sleep, and then I open the windows to ventilate the room, and put the painting on the balcony to dry.
All my creative belongings can be placed on the table, and I put the canvases on a small tabletop easel. Before that, I cover the table with newspapers so as not to stain it. I put a laptop on the windowsill (there is not enough space on the table), and you can listen to music or podcasts while you draw.

So there are options, bro, if you really want to paint with oils! A separate room is not necessary.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6518623
30 minutes: warm-up gesture drawings
5 minute break
30 minutes: copy master drawing
5 minute break
20 minutes: reproduce master drawing from memory
5 minutes: fix mistakes
5 minute break
20 minutes: re-reproduce master drawing from memory with mistakes fixed

when you git gud, do your gestures from imagination and your memory drawings of the master copy you copied the day before, or a week before.

One day a week, shake it up and spend two hours glancing at photo reference and making a 5 minute drawing half-based on your imagination and half-based on your fuzzy memory of the photo reference.

posts.com:
My shitty day 1 paintings have sparked more joy and happiness in the world than anything I've made since I started grinding fundies and caring about being good.

People seriously underestimate the importance of having a more childish, carefree drawing phase. If you got into art late you missed out on this and this is unironically where taste an sovl develops. Instead, people will usually just start out grinding and end up becoming soulless boring retards that only get superficial praise from other artists. But can never create anything soulful or of note.

I'm not against learning fundamentals. It's just that there are pretty much zero notable artists who started with obsessive fundies grinding. They just drew what they liked all day long, learned what they needed, and so on. Versus you who paints cylinders and doomgrinds expressionless floating anime heads in-between shitposting and scrolling.

posts.com: I draw daily and carry around a sketchbook. I draw "for myself" but tactically use my habit to garner attention and feedback from others. Showing the people close to me how much I improve means a lot to me, drawing people I meet is almost always rewarding even if I mess it up people don't care and are interestedin hearing the stories behind a few other drawings, even if it's commentary as simple as "here I was practicing feet" or "this is when me and some friends met and everyone contributed to the sketch!". It's an interesting story because it humanizes the illustrations and gives you motivation to a)improve and b)continue.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6510298
If we are talking about the skill itself of drawing, nepotism can help because someone can teach you how to draw.
But what you wanna sell, a lot of it is social media clout and/or connexions , irl or online.

The bigger the audience the more exposure you get , meaning more people will want to comission you, get enough people to consistently line up for comissions and now you can draw for a living. Pay is not 100% related to skill, sure skill/quality of the actual is an aspect but there are other things, take for example pic rel , how much do you think that should cost based on the quality of the artwork/skill of the artist, anyways this has been sold for 86,4 million dollars.
Let's not forget that comissions are much more "lottery" than a wage to my knowledge, with comissions you might get some rich guy that wants you to draw the most fucked up shit imaginable for a nice sum of cash worth a month's salary for like 4-6 hours of work, and then you might not see a comission for the next 3 months.
As far as I know the "game" goes as follows:
>Draw stuff and improve at drawing
>Post stuff on twitter and wherever tf your tentacles can reach
>Find artist clique of similar skill level and similar audiences
>Start interacting with eachother a lot so followers rub off one another. (maybe develop a legitimate friendship as well , which ever comes first, usually the first "self intrested" one I would say)
>Advertise commissions

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6509789
short answer is: you don't from scratch. as much as artists who like what they do like to pretend, you can't pull internal validation if you never learn to build it, usually it happens during childhood through external validation. I'd bet good money some twitter-famous twats would be swimming in despair if they didn't have their lucky break, they just weren't ignored long enough to reach their breaking point. as for how to build it, I find being goal-oriented with your pieces and making said goal very specific, not something as nebulous as "good". that is as opposed to being result-oriented. accomplishing objectives builds satisfactions and lessens distress over a lack of perceived quality. do this for long enough and it becomes automatic, you start to enjoy yourself more and eventually look forward to the activity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6470632
the eyebrows arent in sync with the eyes hence the delayed action feeling

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6470632
refine the chin placement it follows a rigid pathing make it follow some sort of smooth arch it'll look more natural that way
the bangs have a nice delayed action to them good job : D
also i'd suggest drawing the ears as well even if they're just place-holders cause they'll help keep the head shap from warping with each succesive frame
hold the looking at camera frame for longer before transitioning into the forward leaning motion also make the head a bit farther back in that frame or push it slightly forward in the final pose cuz if you're leaning forward you bend forward slightly rather than rotation forward while being stuck in the same location
also do the eyes completely open first and add the blink after you've smoothened the movement
i get the vibe you're going for but i think you over-stepped in that bit
as is anime eyes are already notoriously difficult to place properly since their orientation depends on the camera angle rather than some defined points in space

you have long way to grow young grass-hopper

>>6491351
The first several frames should look like a ball (yours appears out of nowhere at speed)
Try having fewer frames and less squash when it impacts the ground
It should not slow out from the bounce, so try removing a few frames after the impact
You have blank frames, which is causing blinking; clean it up
As the ball approaches its apex, it should slow down because of gravity, so add more frames. At the top of its bounce it should become its roundest

>>6515254

coders are getting culled long before animators, and lets be real, animation requires way too much control for Ai to probably ever be reliable to use (especially after they get cucked out of their training data in the future). if you're actually a good animator that can get hired for doing animatics / key / breakdown frames or directorial positions, the jobs won't disappear. in-betweeners, colourists and clean-up artists will either have their job drastically downsized or taken out entirely.

there's already so little actually good 2d animated content that gets released every year, just due to the time it takes to produce. there's the very real possibility of a boom / second golden age in animation just from the speed of production we would get. i can imagine a lot of feature length, traditionally animated 2D films (not the shitty fake 2d that always takes its place)

also Ai actually understanding complex movement enough to replicate laws of physics consistently in an appealing manner, enough to compete with what humans have achieved in the past.. i don't see it happening desu, not for 10+ years at least.
